instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the research on profiling and spectral data and quantitative statistical models of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) in tissue specimens?
Output: The research used H-1 HRMAS NMR spectral data for profiling and generating precise models of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) in tissue specimens.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the research on profiling and spectral data and quantitative statistical models of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) in tissue specimens?
Output: CPMG 1H HRMAS NMR Spectra, NOESY 1H HRMAS NMR Spectra, OPLS-DA, PLS-DA

instruction: What metric was chosen for malignancy prediction and how accurate was it in the research on profiling and spectral data and quantitative statistical models of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) in tissue specimens?
Output: The metric chosen for malignancy prediction in the research on profiling and spectral data and quantitative statistical models of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) in tissue specimens. The accuracy of the prediction models in identifying malignancy status among a blinded set of 64 tissues from 12 OSCC patients was reported to be above 90%.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the research on profiling and generating precise H-1 HRMAS NMR spectral and quantitative statistical models of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) in tissue specimens?
Output: Statistical models were used in the research on profiling and generating precise H-1 HRMAS NMR spectral and quantitative statistical models of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) in tissue specimens.

instruction: Can the profiling and generation of precise H-1 HRMAS NMR spectral and quantitative statistical models be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for predicting malignancy in oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) tissue specimens?
Output: Yes, the profiling and generation of precise H-1 HRMAS NMR spectral and quantitative statistical models can be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for predicting malignancy in oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) tissue specimens. The study mentioned in the text demonstrates that these models have successfully identified malignancy status among a blinded set of tissue specimens with an accuracy of above 90%. This suggests that the use of metabolic profiling and statistical models can provide a more accurate and reliable prediction of malignancy in OSCC tissue specimens compared to traditional methods.
